journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Flow analysis of injection-moulded parts with cylindrical microfeatures

article-meta.aff: 1NERC for Advanced Polymer Processing Technology, Zhengzhou University, Henan, People's Republic of China
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA

author-notes.corresp: *NERC for Advanced Polymer Processing Technology, Zhengzhou University, Henan 450002, People's Republic of China. email: ctliu@zzu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Injection moulding a macro-sized plastic part with microfeatures involves multi-dimensional flow and heat transfer behaviours, because there is a substantial difference between the dimensions of macro-sized part and its micro-sized features. How to effectively increase the filling distance of the microfeatures in a macro-sized part is a big challenge. In this study, a method combining both numerical simulation and analytical solution was employed to analyse the flow and the heat transfer behaviours of injection-moulded parts with cylindrical microfeatures. First, finite element and finite difference methods were used to simulate the filling process in the macrocavity based on a generalized Hele–Shaw theory. As a result, the pressure profiles at the entrance of the microfeatures were obtained. Then, the effects of the mould temperature, the injection speed, the dimension of microfeature, and the heat transfer coefficient on the filling distance in the microfeatures were investigated by a non-isothermal analytic method.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Microinjection moulding is one of the widely used processes to fabricate microcomponents due to its mass-production capability and cost efficiency [1]. In general, microcomponents fall into two typical categories: (1) components with overall dimensions in microscale, and (2) components with a dimension in any scale but incorporating microscale features [2]. In the recent years, microcomponents have been increasingly studied and applied in the diverse fields, such as chemistry, consumer electronics, medical, and biotechnology [3–7]. The technologies for injection moulding the plastic parts with low aspect ratio microfeatures, such as CDs and DVDs, have been well developed. However, the flow behaviour of polymer melt in a microcavity is significantly different from that in a macrocavity [8]. Therefore, how to injection mould a plastic part with high aspect ratio microfeatures is still a sizeable challenge.

Traditional software can provide a detailed flow behaviour of a polymer in the macrocavity of an injection-moulded part, but not in its microfeatures due to the substantial dimensional difference between the macrocavity and its microfeatures. If a three-dimensional simulation is conducted for both macrocavity and its microfeatures simultaneously, the tremendous amount of calculations makes such a simulation almost unfeasible. Young [9, 10] employed an analytical method to study the flow behaviour in both macroplate and its rectangular and cylindrical microfeatures. This method is good at predicting the flow behaviour in the microfeatures, but not in the macrocavity. The pressure at the entrances of the microfeatures was either overestimated or underestimated. For the complex part, even the pressure profile cannot be obtained.

The initial pressure at the entrances of the microfeatures is one of the main factors that influence the melt filling distance in the microfeatures. Therefore, the procedures used to obtain the precise initial pressure at the entrance of the microfeatures will further affect the simulation results of the microfeatures. This article employs a new method which combines both numerical simulation and analytical solution to predict the flow and the heat transfer behaviours of injection-moulded parts with microfeatures. First, finite element and finite difference methods were used to simulate the filling process in the macrocavity based on a generalized Hele–Shaw theory. The pressure profiles at the entrance of the microfeatures were obtained. Then, the relationship between the entrance pressure and the filling distance in the microfeatures was established under non-isothermal conditions using an analytic method. In addition, the effects of the mould temperature, the injection speed, the dimension of the microfeature, and the heat transfer coefficient on the filling distance were investigated.

sec.title: 2 MATHEMATICAL MODEL
sec.p:
A schematic description of a mould with cylindrical microfeatures is shown in Fig. 1, where the dimension of the macromould is assumed to be much larger than that of the microfeatures. Under such assumption, the existence of microfeatures has little effect on the filling behaviour of the melt in the macrocavity. Therefore, a generalized Hele–Shaw flow can be assumed in the macrocavity during filling process [11]. Correspondingly, the flow behaviour in the microfeatures can be simplified as the one shown in Fig. 2. The pressure, Po, at the entrance of the microfeatures varies with the position of the melt front in the macrocavity. Due to the small dimension of the microfeatures, the Reynolds number, Re, in the microfeatures is typically very small. In addition, if the surface tension is neglected in the microfeatures, the flow behaviour in the microfeatures can be treated as a pressure-driven one-dimensional laminar flow. Under the above assumptions, the momentum equation in a microfeature can be simplified as (1) where s and r are the filling distances along the flow and the radial directions in the microfeature, respectively, η is the viscosity of the melt, P is the pressure, and νs is the filling velocity of the melt. Fig. 1
The schematic description of a macromould with cylindrical microfeatures Fig. 2
The simplified flow behaviour in a macrocavity with a cylindrical microfeature

The melt in an injection mould can be considered as a power law fluid with viscosity,η, varying with shear rate, γ·n (2) (3) where n is the power law index, m is a function of melt temperature, Ts is the average temperature in the microfeature, T0 is the reference temperature, a0 and m0 is the constants in the viscosity model. Substituting equations (2) and (3) into equation (1) and integrating thereafter yield the relationship between the pressure at the entrance of the microfeature and the filling velocity of the melt in the microfeature (4) where h is the radius of the microfeature. At an instant time, ti=ti-1+Δti-1, the filling distance, s, in the microfeature can be expressed as (5)

According to equation (5), the filling distance, s, of the microfeature varies with the entrance pressure, Po(ti-1), at any moment, ti-1, and is related to the time interval Δti-1. Therefore, the total filling distance can be determined by accumulating all the small changes in the filling distance within every time interval. According to equations (4) and (5), it has been found that both filling velocity and filling distance depend not only on the entrance pressure, Po, but also on the melt temperature-related parameter, β. If the further assumptions are considered as follows: (1) the flow in the microfeature is under quasi-like steady state condition at any instant of time,ti; (2) at the entrance of the microfeature, the temperature is set to be the melt temperature Tm; (3) the mould temperature of the microfeature, Tw, is set to be constant; and (4) the heat conduction is along the radial direction and the heat convection along the flow direction in the microfeature; then the heat transfer equation and the boundary conditions can be expressed as (6) where α is the thermal diffusivity, ht is the heat transfer coefficient, and k is the thermal conductivity of the melt.
The roots of equation (6) can be treated as a sum of two functions T(r,s)=u(r,s)+Tw

where
(7)
Consequently, the temperature field in the microfeature can be obtained as (8) where
In addition, the average temperature, Ts, along the radial direction in the microfeature can be determined as (9)

The parameter λn is satisfied with the following equation (10) where J1 and J0 are Bessel functions. equation (10) can be expressed in the following form (11) which is a polynomial equation of λn with a degree of 2 m. Once λn is obtained by solving equation (11), the average temperature, Ts, of the melt in the microfeature can be obtained by substituting λn into equation (9).

From equation (9), it can be seen that in the microfeature, the average temperature of the melt, Ts, is a function of the filling distance, s, and the filling velocity, vs. Concurrently, according to equation (4), the filling velocity, vs, in turn depends on the average temperature Ts. Therefore, to obtain the filling velocity, vs, and the filling distance, s, within each time interval, first an initial filling velocity is required to determine the average temperature of the melt, Ts, in the microfeature (equation (9)), which is used to calculate the parameter, β (equation (3)), and then the filling velocity is updated by substituting β into equation (4). Such an iteration is conducted until the value of the filling velocity is convergent.

According to the above equations, the flow and the heat transfer behaviours in the microfeature can be determined once the pressure at the entrance of the microfeature is known. The entrance pressure depends on the filling process in the macrocavity, which can be described by a generalized Hele–Shaw flow. Therefore, the momentum and the continuity equations can be simplified to Laplace equation in terms of the pressure, P, [7] (12) where S=∫0 Hz'2ηdz' is fluidity and H the half thickness of the macrocavity.

The corresponding energy equation can be expressed as (13) where u and v are the components of the filling velocity in the macrocavity in x and y directions, respectively, T, ρ, CP, η, and γ· are melt temperature, melt density, specific heat, shear viscosity, and shear rate, respectively.

A finite element equation is formulated in terms of pressure using a control volume method. Also a difference equation is established in terms of temperature in the thickness direction of the macromould. The melt front in the macromould is determined by the volume filling situation in each element [12]. Solving both finite element and difference equations yields the pressure distribution at each point and each moment in the macromould cavity.

sec.title: 3 CASE STUDY
sec.p:
Consider a macromould with length, L = 200 mm, width, W = 50 mm, and thickness, 2 H = 4 mm. It has four cylindrical microfeatures at different locations, which are labelled as A, B, C, and D, as shown in Fig. 1. All cylindrical microfeatures have the depth, D=1000μm, radius, h = 100 µm. The other dimensions of this model are shown in Fig. 1. The material used in this study is ABS (CYCOLAC-EPB), whose properties are listed in Table 1. Table 1
Constants in the viscosity model
m0 (Nsn/m2) a0 Tm (K) T0 (K) n α (m2/s)
3.75 × 105 0.0653 493 381 0.2728 8.1293 × 10−8

Figures 3 and 4 present the melt front varying with filling time and the pressure distribution at the end of filling time of the above-described injection-moulded part, respectively, when the injection rate is set to be, Q = 30 cm3/s. From Figs 3 and 4, it can be seen that in the microfeatures, A, B, C, and D, the variation of melt front with filling time and the pressure distribution at the end of filling time cannot be observed due to a significant dimension difference between the macrocavity and the microfeatures. Fortunately, we can obtain the pressure profiles at the entrance of microfeatures varying with filling time, which are further applied to analyse the flow behaviours in the microfeatures. The pressure profiles of the melt at the entrance of the microfeatures, A, B, C, and D varying with filling time are shown in Fig. 5, where the injection rate is Q = 30 cm3/s. Meanwhile, the pressure profiles at the entrance of the microfeature B with various filling rates are shown in Fig. 6. It has been found that the pressure at the entrance of the microfeature has a linear relationship with filling time, but the slope of pressure versus filling time curves varies with the filling rate. Once the entrance pressure is obtained, the relationships among the filling distances in the microfeatures, the heat transfer coefficient, and the dimensions of the microfeatures can be determined using an analytic method. Fig. 3
The melt front of the injection-moulded part with cylindrical microfeatures varying with filling time Fig. 4
The pressure distribution of the injection-moulded part with cylindrical microfeatures at the end of filling time Fig. 5
The pressure profiles of the melt at the entrance of four microfeatures at different locations varying with filling time Fig. 6
The pressure profiles of the melt at the entrance of the microfeature B varying with filling time at various injection rates

Figure 7 gives the temperature distribution at the different cross-sections of a microfeature having radius of 100 µm under the processing condition as: filling rate 60 cm3/s, and filling time 2.5 × 10−4 s, which is the combination effect of both heat conduction and heat convection. From Fig. 7, it can be seen that along the radial direction of the microfeature, the melt temperature has the lowest value at the mould surface, and varies little at core, which is mainly determined by the heat conduction effect between the melt and the mould. Fig. 7
The temperature profiles of the melt at the various cross-sections and mould temperatures of a microfeature

Figure 8 shows the filling velocity profiles in the microfeature (with radius, h=100 μm, and the heat transfer coefficient, ht=10 000W/(m2·∘C)) at the various mould temperatures and the injection rates. It can be seen that when the melt just reaches the microfeature, the filling velocity is fluctuated due to a large instability of the pressure gradient at the entrance of the microfeature. With an increase in the filling distance and the continuation of melt cooling, the filling velocity gradually decreases. When the melt temperature approaches its glass transition temperature, the filling velocity suddenly decreases to zero and the microfeature can no longer be filled. It is interesting to see that when the mould temperature remains the same, the filling velocity decreases to zero at almost the same time even though the injection rate varies. Therefore, the filling distance in the microfeature increases linearly with the injection rate. It has also been found that the filling time increases with the mould temperature. For example, when the mould temperature is 60°C, the melt stops flowing at 5.1 × 10−4 s after it starts to fill the microfeature, while the total filling time increases to 6.7 × 10−4 s, when the mould temperature increases to 80°C. Fig. 8
The filling velocity profiles of the melt in a microfeature at the various mould temperatures and the injection rates

Figure 9 presents the relationship between the filling distance in microfeatures and the radius of microfeatures at various mould temperatures when the injection rate is Q=60cm3/s, and heat transfer coefficient, ht=10 000W/(m2·∘C). It has been found that the melt cooling rate decreases with an increase in the radius of microfeature, which leads to the filling distance increasing non-linearly with the radius of the microfeature. In fact, equation (4) indicates that the filling velocity is a polynomial function of the radius of a microfeature with a degree of (n+1/n). In addition, the mould temperature has a strong effect on the filling distance. At the same radius of 100 µm, the filling distance is 195.75 µm at mould temperature 40°C. When the mould temperature increases to 80°C, the filling distance increases to 259.95 µm. It suggests that increasing mould temperature might be an effective method to increase the filling distance of microfeatures. Fig. 9
The filling distance in microfeatures with various radius and mould temperatures

The effects of the mould temperature and the heat transfer coefficient on the filling distance in a microfeature are shown in Fig. 10, where the injection rate is set to be Q=60cm3/s. From Fig. 10, it can be seen that at the same heat transfer coefficient, the higher the mould temperature is, the longer the filling distance can be reached. The heat transfer coefficient has a strong effect on the filling distance as well. A higher heat transfer coefficient leads to a faster cooling rate, and therefore a shorter filling distance. Fig. 10
The filling distance in a microfeature at various mould temperatures and heat transfer coefficients

Figure 11 shows the relationship between the filling distance in a microfeature and the thickness of a macrocavity where the microfeature is located at various mould temperatures with the injection rate Q=60 cm3/s, heat transfer coefficient, ht=10 000 W/(m2·∘C), and the radius of the microfeature, h=100 μm. It has been found that the filling distance in the microfeature decreases non-linearly with an increase in the thickness of the macrocavity. The increased thickness leads to a smaller pressure to be built up at the entrance of the microfeature, which results in a shorter filling distance in the microfeature. For example, at the mould temperature of 80°C, when the thickness of the macrocavity is 4 mm, the filling distance in the microfeature is 259.95 µm; when the thickness of the macrocavity reduces to 2 mm, the filling distance in the microfeature increases to 568.8 µm. Therefore, in order to increase the filling distance in a microfeature, a higher pressure at the entrance of the microfeature can be obtained by decreasing the thickness of the macrocavity. Fig. 11
The relationship between the filling distance in a microfeature and the thickness of a macrocavity where the microfeature is located

Figure 12 presents the variation of filling distance in a microfeature with a change in the distance from the entrance of the microfeature to the gate at the injection rate Q=60cm3/s, and mould temperature, Tw=80∘C. It can be seen that the filling distance does not monotonically change with the distance from the entrance of the microfeature to the gate. When a microfeature is far away from the gate, a large pressure cannot be built up. When a microfeature is near the gate, the initial pressure, which is mainly affected by the flow behaviour around the gate, at the entrance of the microfeature, is small. The subsequently built-up pressure cannot overcome the resistance caused by the reduced melt temperature. Therefore, only when a microfeature is at the proper distance from the gate, which is around 60 mm in this case (Fig. 12), can the largest filling distance be achieved. Fig. 12
The relationship between the filling distance in a microfeature and the distance from the entrance of the microfeature to the gate

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this study, a method combining both numerical simulation and analytical solution was employed to analyse the flow behaviour in the injection-moulded parts with cylindrical microfeatures. The factors influencing the filling behaviour in the microfeatures, such as the injection rate, the mould temperature, the dimension of the microfeature, the thickness of the macrocavity, the heat transfer coefficient, and the distance between the microfeatures to the gate, have been investigated. It has been found that the mould temperature and the heat transfer coefficient are the main factors determining the filling distance in the microfeature. Meanwhile, the injection rate, the thickness of the macrocavity, and the dimension of the microfeature also have the strong effects on the filling behaviour in the microfeatures.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Science Foundation of China (grant number 10872186, 11172271).
